Mthi giggles, her laughter light and warm, before she picks up her guitar again. The strings hum softly as she strums a few chords, the sound creating a gentle melody that fills the quiet night air around the campsite.
Mthi: Alright, here’s one of my favorites. It’s a little something I’ve been working on.
She begins to play, her fingers moving expertly over the strings, and the music flows smoothly like a river—soft, flowing, and calming. The melody is simple, yet it carries a depth of emotion, as if each note holds a story that only the music knows. There’s a delicate balance between the rhythm and the silence, with each pause adding weight to the piece.
Mthi: It’s funny how a song can capture everything in a single moment. All the things we don’t say, all the things we feel. Her gaze lifts slightly as she plays, her expression peaceful, lost in the music. The sound of her guitar seems to draw out the stillness of the night, as if the stars above are listening too, swaying in time with the tune.
You: I think that’s the most beautiful thing I’ve heard in a while.
Mthi doesn’t stop playing but looks at you with a quiet smile, her eyes sparkling with the kind of happiness that only music can bring. She continues, the song now wrapping around you like a soft blanket, filling the space with warmth and comfort. It’s a simple song, but it feels like something more - like a gift, something personal just for this moment between the two of you.

You: No thanks, I’m good for now.
Mthi pauses for a moment, her fingers resting on the strings of her guitar, before she flashes you a playful smile.
Mthi: Oh, I see how it is. Well, there’s always a better time for music, right?
She shrugs nonchalantly, her smile not fading in the slightest. With a soft laugh, she returns her attention to the sheet of paper in front of her. Her pencil moves smoothly across the page, writing out new musical notes, each one seeming to take on a life of its own as the melody forms in her mind.
The faint scribbling of the pencil is the only sound now, as she carefully writes out the notes, clearly lost in thought. Her concentration is evident, but the playful energy never fully disappears from her demeanor.
Mthi: murmuring to herself Maybe next time... or the time after that. Music will always be waiting.
She notices you once again.
Mthi: Oh... you're still here. Would you like to hear it now?
She adds, knowing very well you never left.

branches.text: Mthi: Kewl, so now what ?

choices.outcome:
You: So, Mthi, what’s the big dream? What’s the endgame for a musical prodigy like you?
Mthi: Oh, the dream? Definitely to start a band! Like, a real band.
You: A band, huh? Sounds like you’ve thought this through. Got any members in mind?
Mthi: Hmm, well, I did think about recruiting you. But then I remembered... you have the rhythm of a clumsy goblin.
You: Hey, I resent that! I could totally keep a beat.
Mthi: She grins at you Sure, sure. But you’d have to promise not to trip over the drum kit.
You: Fine, scratch me off the list. Who else?
Mthi: Honestly? I think the our group would make an incredible band.... once they learn ofcourse. Just picture it: Llewellyn on bass — he’d have that broody, mysterious vibe all the fans would swoon over.
You: A broody bassist, huh? What about Tino?
Mthi: Oh, Tino? Drummer. Without a doubt. He’d be the chaotic one who plays upside down and smashes everything for fun.
You: That checks out. And Zanele?
Mthi: Lead vocals! She has that soothing, angelic presence that would balance out Tino’s absolute chaos.
You: Practical and talented. What about Jasmin?
Mthi: Hmm, Jasmin would be our manager. No nonsense. Making sure we show up on time, get paid, and don’t, you know, set anything on fire.
You: And you?
Mthi: Lead guitar, of course. I’d be the star... but, like, in a humble way.
You: You laugh Humble, huh? So what’s the band’s name?
Mthi: Oh, I’ve got it: Strings of Destiny. No, wait! The Atlas Mix! Ugh, no, that’s terrible. What do you think?
You: How about The Misfit Chords?
Mthi: laughing Okay, now you’re hired. You can’t play an instrument, but you’ve got the naming skills of a genius.
You: See? I am useful!
Mthi: Mthi smiles at you Alright, fine. Maybe there’s hope for you yet. But if you mess up our first gig, you’re demoted to roadie.
You: Deal.
Mthi: Now, if only I could convince the others... think Tino would trade his time magic for drumsticks?
You: As long as he is not the singer.

You: So, Mthi, what about your family? You must’ve picked up that personality from somewhere.
Mthi: Oh, you mean this sparkling charm? Definitely from my mom. She’s the bubbliest person you’ll ever meet. Always laughing, always chatting—she could probably talk a tree into sprouting flowers.
You: That sounds... lively. What does she do?
Mthi: She’s the head of the Valdoran Guild of Artisans. Fancy title for someone who’s basically a whirlwind with a clipboard, organizing the most talented crafters in the kingdom.
You: That’s impressive.
Mthi: Oh, she’s a force of nature, for sure. My dad’s in the guild too, but he’s quieter. He’s the one making sure the magic-infused tools don’t blow up. Keeps everyone safe while Mom dazzles the crowd.
You: And siblings?
Mthi: My brother’s training to be a Hunter. You know, tracking monsters, surviving in the wild, being annoyingly heroic. And then there’s my sister. She’s the brainiac—studying to be a scholar at the Academy.
You: Scholar, huh? So she’s the responsible one?
Mthi: Oh, completely. She can name every constellation, recite ancient texts, and still somehow judge me for eating dessert before dinner.
You: Sounds like you’ve got quite the family.
Mthi: grinning Yeah, they’re not bad.

Mthi: Valdora is... different. It’s all about balance. The magic, the precision of archery, and the pursuit of knowledge. It’s a land of sorcery and infinite wisdom.
You: Sounds like a dream.
Mthi: Oh, wait till you hear about the library.
You: Library?
Mthi: Not just any library. It’s the largest one in the Known World. Picture this: towering shelves that disappear into the shadows above, scrolls and books crammed into every nook and cranny, the air heavy with the scent of ancient parchment and ink.
You: Sounds incredible.
Mthi: It’s also a maze. You could get lost in there for weeks, and that’s if the archivists let you in. It’s not open to just anyone.
You: I’m guessing they don’t just hand out library cards?
Mthi: Definitely not. I had to sneak in once.
You: Had to?
Mthi: she meets your gaze with a sly smirk Of course! I mean, who wouldn’t want to see ancient scrolls on forgotten spells or stories about bards charming entire armies?
You: Did you get caught?
Mthi: Let’s just say the archivist was very good at stern looks. Told me I was lucky they didn’t turn me into a duck.
You: And?
Mthi: I apologized profusely... and made a run for it. Totally worth it, though.
You: I’m guessing you’re not done sneaking around?
Mthi: Not even close.

You: It’s been fun, Mthi, but I should probably check in on the others before they think I’ve vanished.
Mthi: playfully Oh, you’re leaving me for them? Just when I was about to compose your theme song.
You chuckle, shaking your head. Mthi’s cheerful energy is infectious, and for a moment, you’re tempted to linger. But the faint hum of the campfire and distant murmurs of the others tug at you, reminding you of the night ahead.
You: Save it for my grand entrance next time.
Mthi: Deal. But don’t keep me waiting too long.
As you rise, Mthi leans back, her guitar cradled against her like an old friend, and resumes jotting down notes on her sheet of paper. The soft scratch of her pencil blends with the gentle strum of her strings, filling the air with a melody that seems to follow you as you walk away.
The voices of your companions drift through the stillness, each carrying its own unique cadence, promising new stories and unexpected moments.
You glance back once, catching sight of Mthi, now fully absorbed in her music, her silhouette outlined against the pale light of the stars. A small smile tugs at your lips before you turn your focus forward, ready to see what—or who—awaits you next.

branches.text: Zanele: Mhm, so you were saying ?

choices.outcome:
You: Zanele, do you ever ...fear fire magic? I mean, what it could do — to you, or to those around you?
Zanele: Fear it?
She pauses, her dark oak coloured eyes catching the flickering flames of the campfire as if drawing strength from them.
Zanele: Growing up, I was always taught to fear power. By those above me. They said it was something that could control you, bend you to its will. But you know what? That’s not true — not entirely.
She gestures towards the campfire, the tips of her fingers glowing faintly with ember-like light.
Zanele: Fire ... it’s so much more than just a force to destroy. Yes, it can burn, devastate even, but it’s also life-giving. It’s what keeps us warm on winter nights. It’s how we cook the meals that keep us going, and believe it or not, it can even heal if wielded properly.
She smiles, leaning slightly closer as if sharing a secret.
Zanele: One of my favourite spells is Rekindling flame. It’s an advanced one, but it allows you to use fire to cauterize wounds, sealing them in an instant. Of course, it’s not without its risks—get it wrong, and you’re just setting someone ablaze.
You: Sounds ... intense.
Zanele: That’s the thing about fire magic. It is intense. It demands respect and precision. I’ve spent years honing it, learning its nuances.
Zanele: Another one of my favourites? Inferno. It's more than a spell; it's art.
Zanele steps back slightly, raising her hand with a graceful flourish. Slowly red leaves, tinted with hues of autumn gold and fiery orange, begin to materialize around her.
They swirl gently in the air, as though caught in a warm autumn breeze. The glow they emit bathes the campsite in a soft, radiant light, their edges flickering faintly like embers in the dark.
You watch, captivated, as the leaves descend around you. One leaf drifts closer, and you instinctively reach out.
It feels warm to the touch, delicate like silk but pulsing faintly as though alive.
You: These are... beautiful. They almost don’t feel real.
Zanele: with a sly grin Oh they’re real, all right. And deadly. Once they land on a target...
She snaps her fingers, and one of the leaves hanging in the air flashes briefly before disappearing in a silent puff of fiery red sparks.
Zanele: ...Boom. They explode with devastating impact.
Your eyes widen, and you quickly retract your hand from the leaf you were touching.
You: Wait... WHAT?!
The panic in your voice draws a hearty laugh from Zanele, who waves her hand, dispersing the remaining leaves into harmless embers.
Zanele: Relax! I wasn’t going to blow you up. I’d never waste such a masterpiece on you.
You: Right, thanks! That’s so reassuring.
She smirks and leans forward.
Zanele: Don’t worry—I only explode the people who deserve it.
Her words are lighthearted, but the spark in her gaze makes it clear she means every word.
You can only shake their head in awe and slight disbelief.
Zanele: Fire is balance. It’s not inherently good or bad—it’s the one who wields it that determines what it becomes. You don’t fear fire; you respect it, control it, and let it serve you, not the other way around.
You: That’s ... a lot to take in.
Zanele: It is. But don’t let it intimidate you. Just… don’t tell the others I gave you a crash course. I have a reputation to maintain.
She winks, the playful glimmer returning to her expression.

You: Zanele, I’ve been meaning to ask—what’s your family like? You seem... well, like you’d be the glue that holds everyone together.
Zanele smiles softly.
Zanele: My family? Oh, they’re... a force of nature, truly. Noble bloodlines, scattered far and wide. If there’s a fire-wielder in any corner of the Five Kingdoms, there’s a good chance we’re related somehow.
She pauses, her gaze distant as though she's envisioning faces she hasn’t seen in a while.
Zanele: But at home, the heart of it all is smaller. My time there isn’t spent with diplomats or warriors. It’s with my nephews and nieces.
Her voice grows softer, almost reverent.
Zanele: They’re my little sparks. Every time I visit, they run to me with their wild stories, their impossible dreams, and that innocent belief that I can do anything.
She lets out a small laugh, tinged with nostalgia.
Zanele: I’ll never forget the first time one of them asked me to teach them fire magic. She couldn’t have been older than six. The way she looked at me — like I was this untouchable hero. That’s when I realized... they’re always watching. Every move I make, every word I say—it matters to them.
You can see her composure falter for just a moment, the weight of her words heavy in the air.
You: That must be a lot of pressure.
She shakes her head gently, her tone resilient.
Zanele: Not pressure. Purpose. They’ve shaped who I am as much as I’ve shaped them. They’re the reason I learned to lead with kindness, to stand strong even when it feels like the world’s on fire.
Her smile returns, soft yet resolute.
Zanele: I think that’s why I’ve taken on this role with our group. It’s not about being perfect. It’s about being there — steady, unshakable, and always ready to hold everything together.
For a moment, the two of you sit in silence, the fire crackling softly between you.
You: They’re lucky to have you, you know.
Her gaze meets yours, a flicker of gratitude shows in her eyes.
Zanele: And I’m lucky to have them — and you guys. Family isn’t just who you’re born to. It’s who you fight for, who you stand beside, and who you’ll never give up on.

You: So, Zanele... what’s your home like? I’ve heard rumors about the land of fire, but nothing concrete.
Zanele’s expression brightens instantly, her usual poise replaced with an almost childlike enthusiasm.
Zanele: Ah, Kurohana. There’s nothing quite like it. Hidden high in the mountains, it’s a realm of endless flame and crimson skies. Imagine valleys where rivers of molten lava carve paths through jagged black stone, and the air hums with the energy of fire magic. Even the nights glow faintly, as though the land itself is alive.
She gestures as if painting the scene before you, her words flowing with pride.
Zanele: Kurohana isn’t just a place—it’s a tradition, a way of life. Each clan has its own legacy, passed down through generations. The people there... well, we’re a fiery bunch, no pun intended. Martial arts and fire magic go hand in hand, taught from an early age to channel not just power, but precision and balance.
Her tone shifts, taking on a more thoughtful quality.
Zanele: While other kingdoms might fear fire, we embrace it. We hone it like a blade, tempering its heat until it becomes an extension of who we are.
She pauses for a moment, glancing at you with a sly grin.
Zanele: And of course, Kurohana is famous for its attire — and its women , the best of both, if I do say so myself.
You raise an eyebrow at her joking tone, and she chuckles, clearly enjoying herself.
You: Attire? What makes it so special?
Zanele: Our clothing isn’t just fabric. It’s an expression. Silk dyed in the deepest reds and golds, embroidered with patterns that shimmer like flames when they catch the light.Each design tells a story — of a family, a triumph, a loss, the purity of a marriage, or the quiet strength of a widow. And it’s not just for show. Our battle garments are woven with fire-resistant threads, beads, jewellery and other assets, as functional as they are beautiful.
Her gaze grows distant, a hint of melancholy creeping into her voice.
Zanele: But Kurohana isn’t all beauty. We’ve been at war with Eryndor for as long as I can remember. They see us as a threat, a force to be subdued. Since we are physically opposite Kingdoms, there are bound to be tensions. Our fire magic gives us strength, but it also makes us a target. It’s a complicated history, one with too much bloodshed on both sides.
She sighs, her fingers absently tracing patterns in the dirt.
Zanele: The monsters that roam Kurohana’s lands don’t help, either. Many of them are resistant to fire, which makes them particularly... stubborn. But they’ve shaped us, too. Facing creatures that don’t fear our flames forces us to think differently, to adapt. It’s part of what makes us who we are.
Her eyes flick back to yours, the firelight reflecting in them like molten gold.
Zanele: So that’s Kurohana. Fierce, untamed, and beautiful. Just like its people.
You: It sounds incredible. And dangerous.
She laughs, the sound warm and full of life.
Zanele: Oh, it is. But if you ever visit, don’t worry. I’ll make sure you leave with your eyebrows intact.

Zanele: Enough about me, let’s get to cooking. We’ve got plenty of ingredients—what are we making tonight?
You: How about something hearty? A stew sounds good.
Zanele: Good choice! Let’s get to it. You chop the veggies, I’ll handle the meat and spices.
You begin chopping carrots, onions, and garlic while Zanele prepares the meat. The warmth of the fire and the scent of herbs fill the air.
Zanele: Don’t let the garlic burn—keep it soft and fragrant. Stir it gently.
You: This smells amazing already.
You continue stirring as the stew begins to simmer.
Zanele: Alright, just a pinch more salt... There! Now we wait.

Mthi: Alright, I’ve had enough of listening to Tino's cryptic nonsense for one night. Who’s up for a game?
Zanele: A game? I think we could all use something to pass the time. What do you have in mind?
Mthi: How about a memory game? Cards, matching pairs... it’s simple, but fun.
Tino: Didn't you play that earlier ? Hmmm anyway I'm in. But just so you know, I’ve got the best memory in the group. You’re all doomed from the start.
Llewellyn: Sure, Tino. I’ll believe that when I see it. Let’s see if your memory is as good as you claim.
Jasmin: Alright, alright. We’ll see who’s truly got the sharpest memory. Let’s get started.

Mthi leans back against a log, eyes gleaming with excitement.
Mthi: So, I’ve got an idea! How about a little sing-along? A song for the road ahead! Everyone’s got a voice, right?
Zanele: I’m in! What are we singing? You know I’ve got a thing for tunes.
Jasmin: Sounds fun. I could use a little music to lift the spirits.
Llewellyn: I suppose I can give it a try. It’ll be nice to add something to the night.
Tino, who has been quietly observing, raises an eyebrow and waves his hand dismissively.
Tino: .... Nah, I'll pass.
With a playful grin, Mthi quickly moves closer to Tino, a twinkle in her eye.
Mthi: Oh, come on, Tino! You can’t just leave us to sing by ourselves! It’ll be fun—you might even surprise yourself!
Zanele, ever the supportive force, laughs and nudges Tino lightly.
Zanele: Yeah, Tino! Don’t leave us hanging. You can just sit back and listen, if you must... but you’ll have to hear us.
Tino looks around, then crosses his arms with a smirk, clearly outnumbered but unwilling to give in easily.
Tino: Let it go. I'm not singing but you guys have fun.
Mthi: Alright, Tino, you don’t have to sing—but you’ll be the audience, and we’ll make sure to put on a good show. Just don’t be surprised if we get you humming along by the end of it!

Passion: And so, our journey comes to an end — for now. This game has been a labor of love, countles nights of coding (about above 100 and some spare change), designing, and rewriting. It’s not perfect, and I’ll admit, this is just the beta — the earliest version of what I hope will grow into something far greater.
If you’ve reached this point, it means you’ve joined me on this adventure, and for that, I’m truly grateful. Now, don’t get me wrong — your feedback might matter (I’m kidding, I promise). It does matter because your ideas, thoughts, and opinions could shape what this game will eventually become. Your voice is part of the ideation process now. A massive thank you to my real-life inspirations: Jasmin, Mthi, Llewellyn, and Zanele. Without your unwavering support, humor, and brilliant minds, this project would’ve remained just an idea. You’re the reason this world exists, and your influence is woven into every scene, every choice, and every moment of this story.
Now onto the legalities: I’d also like to acknowledge the incredible assets that helped bring this game to life. Most of the assets used in this project are free and available under the Creative Commons License (CC BY or similar), making it possible for creators like me to dream big.
Thank you for being a part of this story.
~PassionOverPain
